toc_entry.title: Top Gun
toc_entry.description: Texas air chief Frank Lorenzo took an airline with no profits and limited prospects and built it into the country’s largest. How? By betting like the sky’s the limit.

toc_entry.title: Hey, Mom, Have I Got an Assignment For You
toc_entry.description: Once kids did their own homework. Now ambitious parents do it for them.

toc_entry.title: My Sister Is Missing
toc_entry.description: Had she joined some cause? Was it suicide? Or had she wanted to disappear? after months of searching, I found the answer.

toc_entry.title: Petticoat Junction
toc_entry.description: All aboard for this spring’s flounciest fashions.

toc_entry.title: The Inside Story
toc_entry.description: A new breed of home-delivery specialists will bring everything from dinner for eight to a masseur to a dog trainer to your door. Here are more than a hundred to try.

toc_entry.title: It's a Dirty Job, But ...
toc_entry.description: Does the delivery business really deliver? Our author spends three grueling days watching rented videos and ordering pizza to find out the truth.

toc_entry.title: C. W. Post
toc_entry.subtitle: Texas Primer
toc_entry.description: At first he couldn t stand the strain of trying to get rich. Then he couldn’t stand the strain of being rich.

toc_entry.title: A Human Focus
toc_entry.description: Newly discovered photographs taken by Russell Lee bear compassionate witness to the lives of Spanish-speaking Texans in the forties.

toc_entry.title: The Bullock Alumni
toc_entry.subtitle: Politics
toc_entry.description: Caught between the budget crisis and the power of Bob Bullock, politicos are hiring the comptroller’s savvy ex-employees in self-defense.

toc_entry.title: Home Ain’t Where My Heart Is
toc_entry.subtitle: Lifestyles
toc_entry.description: When I was growing up, arlington didn’t have air conditioning or Six Flags. But it did have albert’s Pool Hall and twenty-cent Jax beer, and that made all the difference.

toc_entry.title: Epic Embroidery
toc_entry.subtitle: Movies
toc_entry.description: The action in Platoon is brilliantly sustained, but The Mission falls with a stately thud; The Bedroom Window aspires to be as spellbound as an alfred Hitchcock, but The Defense of the Realm is the engrossing thriller.

toc_entry.title: Pardon Me, Boy, Is That Tex Beneke?
toc_entry.subtitle: Jazz
toc_entry.description: At 73, this Fort Worth jazzman still sings “Chattanooga Choo-Choo,” but he wants new songs, more gigs, and younger audiences.

toc_entry.title: Staying In LInE
toc_entry.subtitle: Texana
toc_entry.description: A group of dancers from Garland, aged 57 to 90, would rather rock on than rock in a chair.

toc_entry.title: Sum Pickens
toc_entry.subtitle: Books
toc_entry.description: Boone, T. Boone Pickens’ autobiography, is most interesting when it names names and tells tales, but such moments surface only occasionally and sink quickly.

toc_entry.title: Reporter
toc_entry.description: Sneak a glance at our inaugural notebook to find out why Clements’ speech didn’t fly, which city had the most imperial ball, and who triumphed in the guv’s snub. Plus: Mad Maxian Car #3, space tombs in the sky, and ZZ Top’s song scuffle.

toc_entry.title: The National Tour Of Texas
toc_entry.description: The Rio Grande Valley never had a valley —except in the minds of developers who invented its name.

toc_entry.title: The Quidnunc
toc_entry.description: Waiting for Perot; sizing up Texas’ legal egos; switching undies with Bobby and Laura Sakowitz.

toc_entry.title: State Secrets
toc_entry.description: A busing controversy at the prison system; the high cost of free rent; the GOP goes to town; a wellknown private eye loses his license; rotten eggs at Bentsen’s breakfasts.
